text: Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t. Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted?

text: Family Member: Ohhhh. Doctor: - outside that prostate gland. So it’s raising in my mind a good dilemma whether to do something for it or not. Patient: Uh huh. Okay. Doctor: On the one hand we have where if it keeps on growing it’s going to cause you major obstruction, blockage, things like that (pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And since you don’t have disease; you know if you had disease in twenty spots which is most people in this situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - with this kind of cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We would say forget why are we even bothering to putting you in harm’s way or side effects way – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - by trying to just take care of the prostate when everything else is out there. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: No I haven’t. Doctor: Okay. So we’d like to check your blood test and then call you and if the PSA is not down to zero then we would consider having you get some radiation treatments and send you for a consultation with the radiation doctors. Patient: Mmm. Doctor: If the PSA does go down to zero then we can tell you about some additional testing that we can do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we may do um your paperwork here - an appointment for six months, just kind of like a safety appointment. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So what you think my tests might be? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll find out by tomorrow. Patient: Okay, that’ll be good.

text: Patient: One slot. Okay. So, if it is filled by the end of next week. Let’s say I, uh, decide not to, uh, take it. Um. Doctor: That person has to be on treatment for a month. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that. Patient: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page. Doctor: Comfortable with that? Patient: I am. Doctor: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that? Patient: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles) Family Member: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question – Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand. Doctor: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Family Member: To qualify for that. Patient: What do they do? Doctor: Oh, no. That’s a specialized scan. Yeah. I mean, he would definitely need a blood draw and all that. Family Member: Right. text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
